description:
I try many to-do apps, but always gravitate to the todo.txt format because it's simple, locally stored, transferrable, and not locked in. Sleek is a nice front end, rather than dealing with a plain text file. I find it works best when you use (A/B/C) priority, +project and @context tags. The UI is a little loose and spacey for me---I like as many items on-screen as possible. 
The Flathub wouldn't launch due to an SELinux glitch (Fedora 40 KDE spin), so I'm working on that.
You might face compatibility issue if you use the archiving feature , as other apps archive in a "done.txt" file; while sleek saves it as "name_of_your_todo_file_done.txt"
summary: Perfect except for an important issue

description: One of the best to-do apps I've tried (and I tried many, including the likes of Todoist and Things 3). I love how simple and, well, sleek it is (which, of course, at least partly is because it relies on the todo.txt format). It has been my daily driver for a few months now. One minor gripe is that Cntrl+N does not work if you're using a different keyboard layout (e.g. Cyrillic) while pressing Cntrl+N. I also so wish there was a mobile sleek app as well ...
summary: Simple, streamlined and cross-platform, totally recommended
